com.tinkerpop.pipes

Interface Pipe<S,E>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    Iterable<E>, Iterator<E>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    FilterPipe<S>, SideEffectPipe<S,T>, SideEffectPipe.GreedySideEffectPipe<S,T>, SideEffectPipe.LazySideEffectPipe<S,T>, TransformPipe<S,E>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractMetaPipe, AbstractPipe, AggregatePipe, AndFilterPipe, AsPipe, BackFilterPipe, BothEdgesPipe, BothPipe, BothVerticesPipe, CollectionFilterPipe, CopySplitPipe, CountPipe, CyclicPathFilterPipe, DuplicateFilterPipe, EdgesVerticesPipe, ExceptFilterPipe, ExhaustMergePipe, ExpandablePipe, FairMergePipe, FilterFunctionPipe, FunctionPipe, FutureFilterPipe, GatherFunctionPipe, GatherPipe, GraphQueryPipe, GroupByPipe, GroupByReducePipe, GroupCountFunctionPipe, GroupCountPipe, HasCountPipe, HasNextPipe, IdEdgePipe, IdentityPipe, IdFilterPipe, IdPipe, IdVertexPipe, IfThenElsePipe, IndexElementsPipe, InEdgesPipe, InPipe, IntervalFilterPipe, InVertexPipe, LabelFilterPipe, LabelPipe, LinkPipe, LoopPipe, MemoizePipe, ObjectFilterPipe, OptionalPipe, OrderMapPipe, OrderPipe, OrFilterPipe, OutEdgesPipe, OutPipe, OutVertexPipe, PathPipe, Pipeline, PipesPipeline, PropertyFilterPipe, PropertyMapPipe, PropertyPipe, QueryPipe, RandomFilterPipe, RangeFilterPipe, RetainFilterPipe, ScatterPipe, SelectPipe, ShufflePipe, SideEffectCapPipe, SideEffectFunctionPipe, StartPipe, StorePipe, TablePipe, ToStringPipe, TransformFunctionPipe, TreePipe, VertexQueryPipe, VerticesEdgesPipe, VerticesVerticesPipe

    public interface Pipe<S,E>
extends Iterator<E>, Iterable<E>
    The generic interface for any Pipe implementation. A Pipe takes/consumes objects of type S and returns/emits objects of type E. S refers to starts and the E refers to ends.
    Author:
    Marko A. Rodriguez (http://markorodriguez.com), Darrick Wiebe (darrick@innatesoftware.com)

    • Method Detail

      • setStarts

        Set an iterator of S objects to the head (start) of the pipe.

      • setStarts

        void setStarts(Iterable<S> starts)
        Set an iterable of S objects to the head (start) of the pipe.
        Parameters:
        starts - the iterable of incoming objects

      • getCurrentPath

        List getCurrentPath()
        Returns the transformation path to arrive at the current object of the pipe.
        Returns:
        a List of all of the objects traversed for the current iterator position of the pipe.

      • enablePath

        void enablePath(boolean enable)
        Calculating paths can be an expensive operation for some pipes. This method is used to activate or deactivate the calculation of paths. The default state of a newly constructed pipe should have its path calculations disabled. An implementation of this method should be recursive whereby the starts (if a Pipe) should have this method called on it.
        Parameters:
        enable - enable path calculations

      • reset

        void reset()
        A pipe may maintain state. Reset is used to remove state. The general use case for reset() is to reuse a pipe in another computation without having to create a new Pipe object. An implementation of this method should be recursive whereby the starts (if a Pipe) should have this method called on it.
